title: When were BGT: The Champions winners Twist and Pulse first on the show?
text:
Twist and Pulse are the champion of champions (Picture: ITV)

The Britain’s Got Talent: The Champions finale was a proud moment all round for Britain, with the winner and runner-ups both being home-grown acts.

But it was Twist and Pulse who were declared champion of champions, just pipping Stavros Flatley.

From Alesha Dixon’s Golden Buzzer to taking home the gold, just when did they first appear on the show – and did they win it then?

Here’s what you need to know…

Who are Twist and Pulse?

Twist and Pulse are a dance duo who first appeared on Britain’s Got Talent in 2010.

We don’t know which one is Twist and who claims to be Pulse, but the talented twosome’s real names are Ashley Glazebrook and Glen Murphy.

Both were born and raised in London – Ashley born in Sidcup and Glen born at Guy’s Hospital.

The pair met and made friends in their secondary school days.

Twist and Pulse have been dancing together for nine years (Picture: Rex Shutterstock)

Ashley, 28, and Glen, 29, both ended up studying for a BTEC National Diploma in dance, ballet, tap dance and jazz dance at the BRIT School of Performing Arts and Technology.

After realising their skill-sets and senses of humour were similar, the duo’s first act together was called Cheeky Boiz, where they created online ‘streetomedy’ (street/comedy) videos.

What year were Twist and Pulse on BGT?

Their online presence led them to audition for Britain’s Got Talent in 2010 and the rest is history.

During their auditions, Ant and Dec said: ‘With their bright outfits and body popping moves, they reminded us of ourselves back in our PJ & Duncan days with one small difference, they could actually dance, and we couldn’t.’

They made it all the way to the final, finishing second to Spellbound.

What did they get up to after Britain’s Got Talent?

Following their first attempt at a BGT win, Twist and Pulse popped up on TV shows including Magic Numbers, where they did a dance made up from the music of massive blockbusters.

Other TV appearances included Celebrity Juice, CBBC’s The Slammer, ITV’s Tenable and BBC One’s Let’s Dance for Comic Relief with Lee Nelson.

In 2013, they were watched by over 400 million people, performing the world’s biggest street dance show on CCTV news.

During the 2012 Olympics, they presented and performed at every date of the 70-day Olympic Torch Relay Tour.

The road to BGT: The Champions

In their return performance to Britain’s Got Talent, the duo got Alesha Dixon’s Golden Buzzer, sending them straight through to the final

When she gave them the buzzer, Alesha said: ‘It’s so refreshing to see you back on the stage. You’re like straight out of a computer game, I could just watch you forever. Love it.’

After being crowned champions, Glen said, ‘I am absolutely speechless.’

Ashley added: ‘Things like this don’t happen to me and my best friend Glen… this means the world to us, honestly.’
